snippet: Both parties’ Congressional leaders indicated after a meeting with President Obama that their goal was a two-step compromise, since they have little time to work before year’s end.
abstract: Pres Obama and Congressional leaders reopen budget negotiations with surprising bipartisan bonhomie, although they must still resolve longstanding dispute over whether to extend Bush-era tax rates for wealthy; both sides indicate willingness to compromise since there is little time to work before end of year, when automatic tax increases and spending cuts will go into effect unless alternative deficit reduction plan is enacted.

byline.original: By JACKIE CALMES and JONATHAN WEISMAN

lead_paragraph: Both parties’ Congressional leaders indicated after a meeting with President Obama that their goal was a two-step compromise, since they have little time to work before year’s end.

headline.seo: At White House Budget Meeting, Old Hurdles and New Attitude
headline.main: At Bipartisan Budget Meeting, Familiar Hurdles but a New Attitude
headline.print_headline: At Bipartisan Budget Meeting, Familiar Hurdles but a New Attitude
